description: The third generation of the World Wide Web based on blockchain technology, enabling decentralized applications and data.
A distributed ledger technology that records transactions across many computers in such a way that the registered transactions cannot be altered retroactively.
A financial system built on blockchain technology that allows for financial services without the need for traditional intermediaries.
A self-executing contract with the terms of the agreement directly written into code.
An organization represented by rules encoded as a transparent, immutable program running on a blockchain.
A digital or cryptographic asset built on blockchain technology that represents a certain value or utility.
A unique digital asset that is not interchangeable with another token of the same type.
A decentralized, open-source blockchain with smart contract functionality.
A decentralized file system that makes the web faster, safer, and more open.
A funding mechanism that incentivizes diversity and quality in open source projects.
Scaling solutions built on top of existing blockchain networks to improve performance and reduce costs.
A decentralized naming protocol for Ethereum.
A virtual world or universe that users can interact with in a virtual environment.
The process of creating a new NFT or token on a blockchain.
A collection of tokens that are locked in a smart contract to provide liquidity for decentralized exchanges.
The process of locking up cryptocurrency to validate transactions and earn rewards on a blockchain.
A token that grants its holders the right to participate in the governance of a decentralized project.
A unit that measures the amount of computational effort required to execute a transaction on the Ethereum blockchain.
A bridge between blockchain and off-chain data sources, providing real-world data to smart contracts.
The ability of blockchain networks to communicate and interact with each other.
A system that allows individuals to control their digital identities without relying on a central authority.
A software application that allows users to manage their cryptocurrency and interact with decentralized applications.
The process by which blockchain networks reach agreement on the validity of transactions and the state of the blockchain.
A consensus mechanism where validators are chosen to create new blocks based on the number of coins they hold and are willing to stake.
A consensus mechanism where miners solve complex mathematical puzzles to validate transactions and create new blocks.
The economic design and structure of a token, including supply, distribution, and utility.
A consensus mechanism where token holders elect delegates to validate transactions and create new blocks.
A system for storing data across a network of decentralized nodes, ensuring data integrity and availability without a central authority.
A separate blockchain that is interoperable with a main blockchain and can handle specific use cases or transactions.
A method of splitting a blockchain's data and transactions across multiple nodes to improve scalability.
A protocol or mechanism that allows assets and data to be transferred between different blockchain networks.
A decentralized platform for trading cryptocurrencies and tokens without a central authority.
A fundraising method where a new cryptocurrency project sells tokens to investors in exchange for funding.
A fundraising method where a new token is sold on a decentralized exchange.
A set of rules and protocols that define how tokens behave on a blockchain, such as ERC-20 or ERC-721.
The base blockchain layer that provides the fundamental infrastructure for transactions and smart contracts.
The maximum amount of gas that can be used in a single block on the Ethereum blockchain.
The price paid per unit of gas to execute a transaction on the Ethereum blockchain.
An application that runs on a decentralized network, typically a blockchain, without a central authority.
A unique identifier created by a cryptographic hash function, used to verify data integrity on a blockchain.
A unit of data containing a set of transactions that are cryptographically linked to the previous block on a blockchain.
A record of a transfer of value or data on a blockchain.
A protocol used by blockchain networks to reach agreement on the validity of transactions and the state of the blockchain.
A software application that allows users to manage their cryptocurrency and interact with decentralized applications.
A protocol that enables interoperability between different blockchain networks, allowing for the transfer of assets and data.
A rewards program that incentivizes users to provide liquidity to decentralized exchanges.
A split in a blockchain network where the community votes on a new set of rules or changes to the protocol.
A mechanism that locks tokens for a specified period, often used for vesting or to prevent early selling.
The optimization of smart contracts to reduce the amount of gas required for execution, thereby lowering transaction costs.
A decentralized network of nodes that provides real-world data to smart contracts without relying on a single authority.
A process of exchanging one token for another on a decentralized exchange.
A security review of smart contracts to identify and fix vulnerabilities.
A network of decentralized nodes that stores data across multiple locations, ensuring data availability and security.
A schedule for releasing tokens to beneficiaries over time, often used in ICOs and other fundraising methods.
A mechanism that returns unused gas to the user, reducing transaction costs.
A system of governance where decisions are made through decentralized means, often involving token holders voting on proposals.
The process of locking tokens to participate in the governance and security of a blockchain network.
The process of improving the efficiency of smart contracts to reduce gas consumption and lower transaction costs.
A platform that allows buyers and sellers to trade goods and services directly without a central authority.
The availability of tokens in a decentralized exchange to facilitate trading and reduce price volatility.
